Text: Does the Participant anticipate making any additional changes to the list of Episode Initiators within the Participant Profile effective for Model Year 3?

The Participant is on track to implement selected Care Redesign interventions within the timeframes indicated within the Care Redesign Plan.
Please provide 2-3 sentences below describing the progress of your high priority Care Redesign Interventions:
Response: The Epic clinical EMR is very supportive of care being delivered for the initial acute episode, and for follow-up care by the AMI nurse navigator and care team, and into the physician offices of our collaborators.  We have developed the ability to get reports on all patients coded to an AMI DRG, who will thus be in the BPCI program.  Our AMI care team has gained great experience following patients across their 90 day episodes.  The cardiac physician champion, the cardiac clinical manager (a physician assistant) and the AMI navigator are all highly committed and now experienced.  In the last 5 months we have added a cardiac pharmacist, who handles discharge medication reconciliation on all AMI patients, and follows-up with them post-discharge.  We have also added a cardiac exercise physiologist who helps AMI patients craft individualized exercise programs.  We have clinical data support for analyzing the claims data.  The Executive Leadership Team is highly engaged at our BPCI Steering Council.

Text: Do you have concerns regarding implementation of any identified Care Redesign Interventions?
Please use the comment box below to provide additional details regarding successes, challenges, and/or barriers to Care Redesign Interventions.
Response: We are working on the CarePort EMR software that would notify us if patients get admitted elsewhere, but this module is not yet installed in several of the regional hospitals where our AMI patients get their local care. Thus unless patients tell us (and we do ask), we are not always aware of ER Visits and Readmissions to other hospitals, until we get the CMS claims data well after the care delivery.  The Telehealth patient tools have been not as robust as desired, nor as accepted by patients as hoped.  Addressing socio-economic barriers to care is an every day challenge.  There can be gaps in the post-acute collaboration (e.g. one patient spent 44 days in a SNF outside our state).

Text: The Participant and/or the Downstream Episode Initiator(s) is on track to implement Certified Electronic Health Record Technology (CEHRT) in a manner sufficient to meet the applicable requirements of the Advanced Alternative Payment Model criterion under 42 C.F.R. & 414.1415(a)(1)(i). To meet this criterion, at least 75 percent of eligible clinicians in each participating APM Entity group, or each hospital if hospitals are the APM Entities, to use CEHRT to document and communicate clinical care.

Text: If selected 'Yes' to question 2, please provide a brief explanation of that process below.
Response: Our hospital and health system provide oversight and coverage for both Clinical Operations and Administrative Support specifically to the BPCI-Advanced Model.  There has been and continues to be broad transparency, collaboration and support in the work done by all teams working on this Program.

Has provision of the beneficiary notification of participation resulted in negative feedback from beneficiaries?
If selected 'Yes' to question 5, what are the primary concerns from the beneficiary perspective?
Has the Participant seen any unexpected positive outcomes associated with implementing BPCI Advanced?
Has the Participant seen any unexpected negative outcomes associated with implementing BPCI Advanced?
If selected 'Yes' to either question 1 or 2, please describe.
Response: 1. We have experienced great engagement of our Executive Leadership Team participating in the BPCI-Adv Steering Team with increased collaboration and understanding of patient care/work flows.2. For patients placed in the AMI Clinical Episode DRG, physicians have had difficulty amending the health record when the Final DRG is issued and that Final DRG is then not indicative for an AMI DRG (ie, upon further diagnostic testing, it is confirmed the patient did not experience an AMI) and before the patient discharge.

Text: Has the Participant established a process for monitoring and mitigating unintended consequences (e.g., patient targeting/avoidance, inadequate or insufficient care, costshifting) associated with implementation of the BPCI Advanced Model?
If selected 'Yes' to question 4, please describe.
Response: Our Executive Leadership Team is interfacing with our Direct Patient Care Team continuously and focusing on the Right Care at the Right Time for every patient (not just the AMI clinical episode).Regarding cost-shifting:  Our teams have also focused on demand-destruction of inpt rehabilitation and keeping patients in an inpt status to reduce costs.Our organization recently revised its Mission and Vision statement to reflect a sharper focus on consumers, overall health, and people's experience.  This update will guide our 2025 strategy called a 'Higher Mark'.  Some attributes of this statement:* High quality in every instance;* Accessible to everyone in every community we serve;* Affordable without ever sacrificing quality;* Worry-free at every touchpoint.Our vision is to be the catalyst that ignites a revolution in health care where everyone benefits from it.

Text: Is there a designated person(s) for coordinating clinical document requests from the Participant and its Downstream Episode Initiators and other clinical partners?
Is the Participant or any of its BPCI Advanced partners under any investigations or subject to sanctions that have not been reported to CMS?
Please describe issues, challenges or barriers associated with implementation of the BPCI Advanced Model that have not being discussed above.
Response: While a report was developed within our EMR to identify BPCI-Adv patients, there has been difficulty in successfully performing Advanced Care Planning (ACP), CPT 99497-99498. The challenges encompass the workflow (difficult to have discussion in every patient instance) and coding & documentation to support the coding requirements (discussion time length to meet of at least 30 minutes).If the patient is not expected to expire from an AMI and the clinician begins the ACP discussion, the patient may become scared of a 'death panel' and/or declines an ACP.  It can be a quick 2-minute discussion and does not meet the code's requirements to bill it.
